div.p: In this paper, a security problem in cyber-physical systems (CPS) is studied. A remote state estimation process using multiple sensors is considered. The measurement innovation packets from each sensor, which may be modified by a malicious attacker, are sent to a remote fusion center through wireless communication channels. To avoid being detected by typical bad data detectors at the remote estimator's side, the attacker would maintain the statistical properties of the measurements. Based on the information extracted from the trusted sensors and the correlations between the the trusted sensors and the suspicious sensors, we propose three sequential data verification and fusion procedures for different detection information scenarios. The corresponding impacts of possible attacking patterns on the estimation performance under different detectors are analyzed explicitly. Simulations are provided to illustrate the developed results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Cyber-physical systems (CPS) refer to the systems combining computational elements with physical entities. With seamless integration of sensing, control, communication and computation, applications of CPS can be found in a wide range of sectors such as smart grid, intelligent transportation and environment monitoring [1], where wireless sensors play important roles due to the essential demand for remote estimation of system states. When compared with traditional wired sensors, advantages such as low cost, easy installation and maintain enable wireless sensors conveniently and simultaneously measuring the system processes and then transmitting information wirelessly to remote control centers. However, the vulnerability of wireless communication channel brings new risks of cyber security threats to CPS. In addition, the increasing penetration to safety-critical infrastructures of the society amplifies the severities under such attacks. Therefore, the security issue is of fundamental importance to ensure the safe operation of CPS and has attracted considerable interest from both academic and industrial communities in the past few years [2]- [6].

There are two major categories of cyber attacks on CPS that are commonly investigated in the literature [2]: deception (integrity) attacks (corresponding to the traditional security goal: integrity), and denial-of-service (DoS) attacks (corresponding to another goal: availability). The former ones focus on modifying the information in the transmitted data packets, while the latter ones block the exchange of information among parts of CPS. As such, though the loss of information would degrade the estimation performance, when the attacker could access the data and modify it intentionally, the misleading information might cause further negative impacts on the operation of systems, and making the integrity attacks more difficult to detect. Therefore, the complexity and importance to investigate the integrity attacks motivate intensive research efforts [4], [7], [8].

Intuitively, if the data is modified under integrity attacks, the statistical properties in general change accordingly. Motivated by such observation, the residue-based χ 2 detectors are widely deployed to distinguish attacks by checking the characteristics of the received data [7], [9]. However, simply relying on the individual information and properties of each measurement data may leave loophole for the adversaries. In [8], the authors considered integrity attacks against parameters estimation in smart grids. By exploiting the configuration parameters of a power system and properly choosing the false data, the proposed attacking patterns for different attacker capability scenarios can bypass the failure detector and inject arbitrary deviations in the state estimate from its true value. Similar results can be found in [4]. In [10] the authors considered linear deception attacks on a linear estimation process; they derived the optimal strategy for the attacker in the sense that the state estimation error achieves maximum value while the modified data still keeps the same statistical distribution as the original. When multiple sensors were deployed, a gametheoretic approach was provided in [11], where the remote estimator was designed to distinguish and utilize the sensor measurements that may be potentially corrupted by a malicious attacker to estimate a binary random variable. The estimator aimed to minimize the probability of the estimation error while the attacker had an opposite objective; a computational efficient sub-optimal estimator was also provided.

In this work, we study the problem of detection against integrity attacks on multiple sensors for remote state estimation of a dynamic process. We extend the parameter estimation of a static model considered in the work such as [4], [7], [8], [11], to a dynamic process, which can be regarded as a more general description of CPS applications. Motivated by the results in [10] for the single sensor case, we propose a multisensor framework. If the remote estimator would still adopt a standard χ 2 detector in the multi-sensor case and verifies the data based on their statistical characteristics before processing them, we show that it will fail to distinguish the modified data as in [10]. To improve the detection and estimation performance, we investigate how to extract the information from trusted sensors and based on such information and the correlation between sensor measurements to examine the unreliable measurements. Instead of the one-sided analysis of the attacker's optimal solution for the single sensor case in [10], we propose three sequential data verification and fusion procedures for different detection information scenarios based on the analysis of possible attacker's behavior.
The main contributions of the present work are summarized as follows:

1) We study the optimal deception attacks in a multi-sensor remote estimation framework, which is a more general model and description for real applications. 2) We propose three sequential data verification and fusion procedures for different detection scenarios based on the information extracted from the trusted sensors and the correlation between the sensors. We also derive the optimal parameters for the last two detectors (Theorem 4.4).
3) The corresponding impacts of possible attacking patterns on the estimation performance under different detectors are analyzed explicitly (Lemma 3.2 and Theorem 4.2).

The optimal linear deception attacking strategy is also derived (Lemma 4.3). The remainder of the work is organized as follows. Section II presents the system framework and preliminaries about the linear deception attacks in the single sensor case. Section III considers this security problem in a multi-sensor framework. Section IV proposes three sequential data verification and fusion procedures for different detection scenarios. Numerical examples and simulations are demonstrated in Section V. Section VI provides some concluding remarks.

div.head: B. Remote Estimation for the Single-sensor Scenario
div.p: At each time step, each sensor will send its own measurement data to a remote estimator through a wireless communication network.

Due to the development of manufacturing technology, most modern sensors are equipped with on-board chips and have computation capacities and are thus called "smart sensors". Therefore, for the single sensor case, the sensor can first locally process the raw measurement data to obtain a local a priori estimate xk|k-1 and send the innovation of the measurements compared with xk|k-1 instead (e.g., [10]), where the innovation is defined as
div.formula: z k y(k) -C xk|k-1 .

div.formula: 1) z k is zero-mean Gaussian; 2) z k and z j are independent, ∀j ̸ = k; 3) Σ z E[z k z ′ k ] = CP C ′ + R.
div.p: Sending the innovation (zero-mean Gaussian) instead of the raw measurement is communication-efficient, which can reduce the communication bandwidth and the energy consumption of the sensors due to a lower average signal magnitude [14]. In addition, the innovation will approach a steady-state distribution. From the perspective of security, the zero-mean white Gaussian distributed innovation of the sensor's measurement will enable the remote estimator to detect the abnormal data that may be modified by potential cyber-attackers more easily than the raw data. On the other hand, as stated in the papers dealing with quantized control and estimation, e.g., [15]- [17], if the quantization is carried out for sensor's raw measurement, a larger quantization noise will be generated if the values of the raw measurements are large. As a result, sending raw measurements leads to information loss and lower estimation accuracy. Therefore, sending innovation 1 instead of raw measurements is widely adopted in the literature, e.g., [10], [15]- [19].

div.head: C. Optimal Linear Deception Attacks
div.p: In many applications, the residue-based χ 2 detectors are deployed at the remote estimator's side by checking the statical characteristics of the innovation data (e.g., [7], [9], [10]). A typical χ 2 detector for the innovation z k adopts the following hypothesis testing:
div.formula: ξ k = k ∑ i=k-J+1 z ′ i Σ -1 z z i H0 ≶ H1 η,(3)
div.p: where the null hypotheses H 0 represents that the received data is normal while H 1 is on the contrary, J is the window size of detection and the threshold η is to be designed properly. As z k is i.i.d. Gaussian, ξ k is χ 2 distributed with Jn y degree of freedom. If the statistic ξ k exceeds a certain threshold η, an alarm will be triggered and the current measurement will be dropped. However, though this type of detector works well against many types of integrity attacks, the results in [10] showed that by designing the strategies properly, the attacker can inject 1 When the sensors send raw measurements to the estimator, the estimation process will keep the same. div.head: III. LINEAR DECEPTION ATTACKS IN THE MULTI-SENSOR SCENARIO
div.p: Though the linear deception attacks cannot be detected in the single sensor case, the story when the remote estimator receives data from multiple sensors will be different.

div.head: A. Remote Estimation for the Multi-sensor Scenario
div.p: For the multi-sensor scenario, we need to fuse all the measurements from different sensors at the same time step. Denote Y k {y 1 (k), y 2 (k), ..., y N (k)} = {y 1:N (k)} as the measurements set for the remote estimator at time step k. Define:

Similar to the single sensor case, to reduce the communication bandwidth and for the security purpose (the innovation will approach a steady-state distribution that can be easily checked by a false data detector), each sensor will also first locally process the raw measurement data and send the innovation of the measurement to the remote estimator. However, in the multi-sensor scenario, each single sensor cannot compute the a-priori estimate xk|k-1 at the remote estimator's side based on its own measurements. Therefore, one efficient way is that the remote estimator broadcasts its xk|k-1 at each time step to reduce the communication costs of the sensors (the remote estimator can access the information from other sensors and more energy resources than a single sensor). Under such a protocol, the innovation sent by each sensor is defined as:

div.head: B. Linear Deception Attacks on Multiple Sensors
div.p: Suppose that we have a group of sensors in secure places and their measurements are guaranteed to be reliable (similar settings can be found in [3], [21]). For convenience, denote the set of "safe" sensors as S with its cardinality represented by |S| = M and the set of the rest unreliable sensors as A = N \S with |A| = N -M . Without loss of generality, we assume that the sensors i = 1, 2, ..., M are "safe" and the rest sensors are unreliable.

div.p: Remark 3.3: Based on Lemma 3.2, the original data and the modified data follow different distributions, which provides a foundation to verify the authentication of the received data. Clearly, when the attacker does not modify the data, i.e., T k = I, we have Σ H1 = Σ H0 . On the other hand, consider a simple example: a one-dimension system with all parameters being scalar. When the attacker selects the optimal linear deception attacks parameters as in the single sensor case (T k = -1), the impact of the attack on the estimation performance will be significantly increased. However, the gap between Σ H1 and Σ H0 will reach the maximum, which will help the failure detector to better distinguish the deception data from the original data. In the meanwhile, one can also note that the distribution of the modified data, namely, Σ H1 , depends on the attacking pattern T k chosen by the attacker and the detector may not access such information. Therefore, the optimal forms of the detector may vary based on the information or knowledge holding by the attacker and the estimator, which we will discuss in details in the following section.

div.head: IV. ATTACK DETECTORS IN DIFFERENT INFORMATION SCENARIOS
div.p: To investigate this security problem more comprehensively, we will consider the optimal detectors in different information scenarios in this section.

div.head: A. Ordinary Detector: Limited Information Scenario
div.p: As stated before, since the distribution of the modified data (Σ H1 ) depends on the attacking pattern T k chosen by the attacker, the detector may not have access to such information, thus cannot acquire the exact properties of the modified data. As a consequence, one standard method is to propose the following χ 2 detector only to check whether the received data is original or not (merely using the information Σ H0 ):
div.formula: ξ 1 k,a k ∑ i=k-J+1 z ′ i,a Σ -1 H0 z i,a H0 ≶ H1 η, (19
div.p: where the threshold η is a designed parameter. If the condition of H 0 in ( 19) is satisfied, the received data zk,a will be used to further update the estimation. Otherwise, the data will be abandoned.

Though the updated innovation z k,a has different distributions depending on whether under attack or not, it is zeromean Gaussian in both cases. Therefore, under the proposed detector (19), the remote estimator needs to tradeoff the false alarm with the potential damage due to fusing the modified measurements by tuning the threshold value.

div.head: B. Improved Detector: Sufficient Information Scenario
div.p: As discussed in the last part, if the remote estimator has extra information and can infer possible behavior of the attacker, it can modify the detector by integrating such information to improve the estimation performance. To be more specific, consider the case where the attacker still assumes the remote estimator running the classic χ 2 detector as in (3) for every single sensor's innovation in parallel at the beginning of each time step.

From the perspective of the attacker, for such case, it only needs to maintain the distribution of the modified innovation as the original one as in (9). div.head: V. SIMULATIONS
div.p: In this section, we will present some numerical examples to illustrate our results.

Consider a two-dimensioned system with parameters: The empirical examples are generated via 10000 Monte Carlo simulations. Typically, the state estimation error covariance will diverge from its original value exponentially fast under constant deception attacks if the remote estimator fails to detect them. Therefore, in the following simulation, the attacks are conducted in a time horizon of 5 time steps and we assume that the process already enters steady state before attacks.

For the given system, the estimation performance under detector in (19) (denoted as D1) with different thresholds are presented in Fig. 2(a). With the knowledge of the a-priori information, the estimation performance under the detector in (25) (denoted as D2) is also shown in Fig. 2(a) for comparison. For illustration purpose, the estimation performance of using all the sensors assuming they have not been attacked is provided as benchmark 1, the one of using only the safe sensor is provided as benchmark 2, and the one of using sensors that are not modified is denoted as benchmark 3 . Obviously, both detectors D1 and D2 can help improve the estimation performance than only using safe sensors (benchmark 2) by properly choosing the threshold. However, by utilizing extra information, better estimation performance is achieved under (25) (D2) than under (19) (D1), while the gap still exists between them and the performance benchmarks 1 and 2. In our current parameter settings, the condition in (34) is not satisfied, thus we may not achieve a better estimation performance by recovering the original data from the suspicious data due to the high false alarm rate. As a counter-example shown in Fig. 2(b), due to the relatively high false alarm rate, the detector with the recovering procedure in (32) may wrongly recover the suspicious data that is not modified, which will result in worse performance even than just utilizing the safe sensors (benchmark 2). Now we consider the same two-dimensioned system with different parameters as π 0 = 0.2, π 1 = 0.8. The condition in (34) is satisfied now and thus we can obtain a better estimation performance by using detector D2 with the recovering procedure. As shown in Fig. 3, detector D2 with the recovering procedure in (32) provides improved performance than detector D2 without the recovering procedure. However, the gap still exists between them and the benchmark 1. We considered a typical remote estimation process using multiple sensors. To detect the suspicious data sharing the same statistical properties as the original measurements, we proposed three sequential data verification and fusion procedures for different detection information scenarios based on the information extracted from the trusted sensors and correlations among the sensors. The corresponding impacts of possible attacking patterns on the estimation performance under different detectors were analyzed explicitly. Future work directions include investigating the responses of the attacker to the new detector and the dynamic-decision process between the attacker and the estimator under a game-theoretic framework.
